docs.snippet: CAL DEAL admires Denzel Washington's skill in front of a camera, but he did not applaud Mr. Washington's nomination yesterday for the best actor Oscar. Mr. Deal maintains a Web site titled, ''Hurricane Carter: The Other Side of the Story,'' and it...
docs.lead_paragraph: CAL DEAL admires Denzel Washington's skill in front of a camera, but he did not applaud Mr. Washington's nomination yesterday for the best actor Oscar. Mr. Deal maintains a Web site titled, ''Hurricane Carter: The Other Side of the Story,'' and it portrays a lying thug who bears little resemblance to the martyr played by Mr. Washington in the movie ''The Hurricane.'' ''It appalls me to see a man I consider a triple-murderer put on a pedestal,'' said Mr. Deal, whose view is controversial, to say the least. It is absent in the movie and in much of the press coverage of the case. But it is not unique, either, at least not among those who have been following the case as long as Mr. Deal has.
docs.abstract: John Tierney The Big City column discusses Web site maintained by Cal Deal that portrays Reuben (Hurricane) Carter as lying thug who was guilty of murder; Deal, journalist, discusses his examination of case records and reasons why he sees Carter as triple murderer; assails Carter's portrayal as an innocent victim in movie The Hurricane (M)

headline.main: The Big City; 'Hurricane' Motivates A Real Critic

docs.section_name: Technology; Movies; New York and Region

docs.snippet: NEWS    Safe Haven  A campaign by writers and scholars to spare William Butler Yeats's final Dublin home from demolition appeared headed for success yesterday after receiving support from Ireland's heritage minister. ''The house is an early 18th-c...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEWS Safe Haven A campaign by writers and scholars to spare William Butler Yeats's final Dublin home from demolition appeared headed for success yesterday after receiving support from Ireland's heritage minister. ''The house is an early 18th-century dwelling and is itself of intrinsic heritage value,'' said the minister, Sile de Valera. ''Its association with Yeats adds to that value.'' Although the minister has only an advisory role, his statement made it unlikely that local officials would allow a developer to proceed with plans to raze the house, Riversdale, to make way for 28 apartments on on the southern outskirts of Dublin. Yeats, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1923, wrote about Riversdale in his poems ''An Acre of Grass'' and ''What Then?''
docs.abstract: Campaign by writers and scholars to spare William Butler Yeats's final Dublin home from demolition appears headed for success after receiving support from Ireland's heritage minister; more than 230 art masterworks assembled by Stroganoff family of St Petersburg go on view Feb 19 at Portland Art Museum in Oregon; photo; show Ballads and Ballots, by Oscar Brand, to be presented at 92d St Y; Honore Daumier retrospective to go on view at Philips Collection in Washington; photo (M)

docs.snippet: McCURLEY-Nora Esther. In her 93rd year, died peacefully on February 11, 2000 after a short illness. She is survived by her sister Elsa M. Crosa and daughters Doreen McCurley and Mary Lukinich and son-in-law Rex Lukinich. A requiem mass will be hel...
docs.lead_paragraph: McCURLEY-Nora Esther. In her 93rd year, died peacefully on February 11, 2000 after a short illness. She is survived by her sister Elsa M. Crosa and daughters Doreen McCurley and Mary Lukinich and son-in-law Rex Lukinich. A requiem mass will be held at St. Agnes Church, 143 East 43 St. at 10:00 AM on Thursday, February 17. Interment will be at Arlington National Cemetery next to her beloved husband, Oscar Guinn McCurley.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCURLEY, NORA ESTHER

docs.snippet: MAYBE it all started when his mother, with the frugality-before-frivolity ethos practiced by so many Depression-era moms, wouldn't let him have a canine companion back in Boston no matter how passionately he pleaded. Then as now, for Chester F. Co...
docs.lead_paragraph: MAYBE it all started when his mother, with the frugality-before-frivolity ethos practiced by so many Depression-era moms, wouldn't let him have a canine companion back in Boston no matter how passionately he pleaded. Then as now, for Chester F. Collier, dogs are serious, serious business. That's why nothing makes the 72-year-old Mr. Collier, Westminster Kennel Club's president, more uptight than his duty to emerge, in tuxedoed splendor, from a two-day sequestration straight into Madison Square Garden's main arena tonight to anoint the lucky dog who will be the new king (or queen) of the canine universe.
docs.abstract: Public Lives column profiles career of Chester Collier, president of Westminster Kennel Club; photo (M)

headline.main: A Dog Lover Finally Has His Day as Judge

docs.snippet: Thanks to Jorg Haider's Freedom Party, Vienna has two new schools of art: the small and bitter Get-Out-Now movement and the larger, angrier Stay-and-Fight club.    The first wants a complete art blockade of Austria to protest the inclusion of Mr. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks to Jorg Haider's Freedom Party, Vienna has two new schools of art: the small and bitter Get-Out-Now movement and the larger, angrier Stay-and-Fight club. The first wants a complete art blockade of Austria to protest the inclusion of Mr. Haider's right-wing anti-immigrant party in a coalition government. The latter plans to stay and protest his ascendancy.
docs.abstract: Austria's arts and cultural community is roiled by rise of Jorg Haider and his Freedom Party, and debates strategy to combat situation; one faction seeks complete art blockade of Austria to protest inclusion of Haider's right-wing party in coalition government; another faction plans to protest his ascendancy (M)

headline.main: Austria Under Siege By Artists (and Artifice)

docs.snippet: JAMES GALWAY, the most often recorded and, by most appraisals, the best flute player in the world today, has never been content to stay with the tried and true.    ''I'm glad I don't play the fiddle,'' he said a few years ago. ''I'd be Mendelssohn...
docs.lead_paragraph: JAMES GALWAY, the most often recorded and, by most appraisals, the best flute player in the world today, has never been content to stay with the tried and true. ''I'm glad I don't play the fiddle,'' he said a few years ago. ''I'd be Mendelssohn-ed out of my mind.'' His dozens of commissions and transcriptions have enormously broadened the repertory for his instrument, and he not only encourages new music but also battles for it to be included on concert programs.

docs.snippet: Bronx Museum of the Arts  1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th  Street, Morrisania  Through Feb. 27      ''Amnesia'' is a persuasive example of a familiar exhibition format: the broad-spectrum traveling group show of Latin American artists united under ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bronx Museum of the Arts 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, Morrisania Through Feb. 27 ''Amnesia'' is a persuasive example of a familiar exhibition format: the broad-spectrum traveling group show of Latin American artists united under a catchy, one-size-fits-all theme. Several of the 16 participants -- from Argentina, Brazil, Colombia and Venezuela -- will be familiar to New York audiences. The exhibition itself (which, oddly, includes only two women) was organized by a pair of commercial galleries in Los Angeles, Christopher Grimes and Track 16. The Grimes gallery has given at least three of these artists solo gallery shows.
docs.abstract: Holland Cotter reviews art exhibit Amnesia, which features works of Latin-American artists, at Bronx Museum of Arts; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: Theater    ''JEKYLL AND HYDE.'' Theaterworks/USA presents Robert Louis Stevenson's gothic thriller, transformed into a one-hour contemporary musical about a teenager who can't say no to drugs. The play is suitable for ages 8 to 12. Book and lyrics...
docs.lead_paragraph: Theater ''JEKYLL AND HYDE.'' Theaterworks/USA presents Robert Louis Stevenson's gothic thriller, transformed into a one-hour contemporary musical about a teenager who can't say no to drugs. The play is suitable for ages 8 to 12. Book and lyrics are by David Crane and Marta Kauffman; music is by Michael Skloff. Auditorium at Equitable Center, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 52nd Street, tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 p.m. (also Feb. 19-20). Tickets $19. Reservations: (212) 627-7373. ''MAMET FOR KIDS.'' You wouldn't expect David Mamet to write fairy tales or other works for children, yet he has written two that have the playwright's stamp without his famously colorful language. ''The Poet and the Rent'' (10 a.m.) and ''The Frog Prince'' (11:30 p.m.) will be presented tomorrow by Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea. Tickets: $10; $5 for children under 10. Reservations: (212) 633-2643.

docs.snippet: As major Web sites came under day-by-day attack by computer pranksters this week, so have Bryant Park's fashion shows been disrupted by rolling anti-fur protests.     A third catwalk was singled out yesterday morning by a protester who aimed red p...
docs.lead_paragraph: As major Web sites came under day-by-day attack by computer pranksters this week, so have Bryant Park's fashion shows been disrupted by rolling anti-fur protests. A third catwalk was singled out yesterday morning by a protester who aimed red paint from a juice bottle at a fur-wearing model in the Randolph Duke show. He succeeded mainly in splashing journalists and a stylist in the front row, staining their pricey handbags and a lime green cashmere sweater.
docs.abstract: Fur protesters have been interrupting Bryant Park fashion shows all week; latest incident involved protester who unsuccessfully spattered runway model at Randolph Duke show; photos (M)

headline.main: Fur Protesters Interrupt Shows, but Barely

docs.snippet: In the wake of his loss to Felix Trinidad, Oscar De La Hoya has dropped the veteran trainer Gil Clancy and turned up the heat in his training camp in preparation for his Feb. 26 fight against Derrell Coley at Madison Square Garden.     It was Clan...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the wake of his loss to Felix Trinidad, Oscar De La Hoya has dropped the veteran trainer Gil Clancy and turned up the heat in his training camp in preparation for his Feb. 26 fight against Derrell Coley at Madison Square Garden. It was Clancy who told De La Hoya to stay away from Trinidad over the last four rounds after De La Hoya had seemingly built up a huge lead on points in their bout on Sept. 18. It turned out to be bad advice. He gave away the last four rounds and lost a controversial decision.
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya, preparing for February 26 fight against Derrell Coley at Madison Square Garden, NYC, dismisses veteran trainer Gil Clancy (S)
